intro: Serapias lingua var. parviflora, commonly known as the small-flowered sandwort, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the family Rockcress (Capparaceae) and is characterized by its low-growing, mat-forming habit. The plant features showy, yellow-orange flowers with a distinctive bilabiate structure, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are fleshy and succulent, adapted to thrive in dry, sandy soils. This variant is distinguished by its smaller, more compact flowers compared to other varieties within the Serapias genus.
